responsive website for film festival voting

FilmVote

responsive website ui/ux

My Role
Project Lead
UI/UX Design
UX Research

Team
Aubrey K. Young (Solo)

Project Duration
2 months

the situation

Independent film fans want a secure and transparent way to vote for independent film festival movie entries.

the goal

Design a responsive website that allows users to watch, review, and rate independent movies for upcoming film festivals.

Understanding the user

Research Summary

I conducted 5 interviews to understand common behaviors, experiences, and frustrations with users who have attended a film festival in the recent past and use modern technology to watch films.

Goal: I want to understand common behaviors, experiences, and frustrations with users who regularly stream long-form media & who are involved with or interested in independent film festivals.

Participants: Adults between 19-45 years old and of different ethnic/cultural backgrounds, who live and work in metropolitan or suburban areas. My initial assumptions included those who are duly familiar with movie streaming technology.

research results

The following pain points emerged from my initial user study, as follows:

1
users want to increase voter participation in independent movie voting
2
users want to increase confidence in the independent movie awarding process by voting securely

personas

After analyzing the interview data, 2 personas emerged:

Low Fidelity Design

My Approach

To keep this project within scope while also focusing on making a site that is easy to navigate, my approach targets indie movie-goers during the voting process. The social and networking aspects can be implemented on further iterations.

User Journey

Raymond’s user journey goal is to cast a secure vote in an upcoming film festival.

Sitemap

Once I got into the design process, I went with the “less is more” philosophy and pared down the site for a more streamlined minimum viable product.

Lo-fi Wireframes (Paper)

I emphasized the small images and expansive screens to mimic modern streaming service layouts. This flattens the learning curve for new users to start watching movies quicker.

Lo-fi Wireframes (Digital)

I emphasized large, engaging images reminiscent of a streaming service, and a signup button above the fold to engage users immediately.

Usability Testing

  • same 5 participants from the User Study
  • moderated study
  • ~10 minutes per study

    • The following findings emerged from this round of usability testing, which I used to create my hi-fi mockups.

    1
    "I wasn't sure at first where to sign up, so I went for the menu. I used the sign-up button there."

    Problem: Users clicked the navigation button to sign up instead of a prominent Call-to-Action button

    Solution: I placed the Call-to-Action ("Sign me up!") button prominently above the fold.

    2
    "There's a lot of information on the rate and review screen; I might want to rate the movie immediately after watching, but review it later."

    Problem: users appreciated one less screen to navigate before being able to rate and review movies

    Solution: I created a toggle between the review and rate screens, instead of 2 separate screens.

    High Fidelity Design

    Colors & Fonts

    FilmVote's blue and yellow colors are purposefully opposing to draw the user's eye to the site's main functions. The image-dominant sections have a light background to allow the movie posters to stand out.

    #004ba0
    #f8bc39

    Poppins is a clean, modern, and geometric font. Readability and many different font variants make it a very useful typeface.

    coup de grâce: final screens

    FILMVOTE represents a responsive website that includes a secure voting system and an interface reminiscent of modern streaming sites.

    DESKTOP:

    MOBILE:

    Following Steps

    As connected as we are today, I feel there are certain media outlets that could use a voting and discussion aggregate separate from the leading social media apps. Book-centered app Goodread would benefit greatly from a rate/review/share system, as would movie or music streaming services.

    My next step improvements would include:

    1
    Niche discussions
    Expanding the voting system to other forms of media, i.e. books and music
    2
    Movie tags
    Movie tagging to allow for streamlined categorization and searching for specific movie genres
